parts.text:
Choose from: decreased, stayed the same, increased.

As the number of lamps increased, the current ___.

As the number of lamps increased, the total resistance of the circuit ___.

As the number of lamps increased, the potential difference across the battery ___.
When there were three lamps in the circuit the ammeter reading kept changing between 0.35 A and 0.36 A. What type of error would this lead to?

Figure 3 shows a circuit with five ammeters and three identical lamps.

Complete the readings:

A2 = ___ A

A5 = ___ A
The resistance of one lamp is $15\,\Omega$. The current in the lamp is $0.12\,\text{A}$. Calculate the power output of the lamp using $P = I^2 R$.

Figure 1 shows a circuit diagram.

Choose from: J, K, L, M.

In which position could a switch be placed so that both lamps can be switched on or off at the same time? ___
Draw the circuit symbol for a switch.
In $30\,\text{s}$, $24\,\text{C}$ of charge flow through the battery. Calculate the current in the battery using $I = \frac{Q}{t}$.
There is a potential difference of $3.6\,\text{V}$ across the battery. Calculate the energy transferred when $60\,\text{C}$ of charge flows through the battery using $E = QV$.
Figure 2 shows Circuit X and Circuit Y built using identical components. How would the reading on the ammeter in Circuit Y compare to the reading on the ammeter in Circuit X?
options: The reading in Y would be higher.
The reading in Y would be lower.
The readings would be the same.
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer B (reading in Y would be lower)

parts.text: How does the total resistance of Circuit Y compare with the total resistance of Circuit X?
options: The total resistance of Y is greater.
The total resistance of Y is less.
The total resistance is the same.
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer A (total resistance of Y is greater)

parts.text: Write down the equation which links current, potential difference and resistance.
markScheme: 1 mark: $V = IR$ (or potential difference = current × resistance)

parts.text: Figure 3 shows a circuit with a single lamp. There is a potential difference of $3.6\,\text{V}$ across the lamp and the current through the lamp is $0.80\,\text{A}$. Calculate the resistance of the lamp.
Draw a diagram to show how $1.5\,\text{V}$ cells should be connected to give a potential difference of $4.5\,\text{V}$. Use the correct circuit symbol for a cell.
markScheme: 1 mark: correct circuit symbols for cells
1 mark: 3 cells in series with correct orientation (adds to 4.5 V)

parts.text: A student built the circuit shown in the diagram. The potential difference is $12\,\text{V}$ and the current is $1.6\,\text{A}$. Calculate the total resistance of the circuit using $R = \frac{V}{I}$.
The resistance of resistor P is $3.5\,\Omega$. Using your total resistance from part (b), calculate the resistance of Q.
The student connects the two resistors in parallel. What happens to the total resistance of the circuit?
Give a reason for your answer to part (d).
markScheme: 1 mark: e.g. more than one path for charge / total resistance less than smallest resistor / current would be higher for same p.d.

parts.text: What is the frequency of the mains electricity supply in the UK?
What is the potential difference of the mains electricity supply in the UK?
The vending machine applies a potential difference of $0.45\,\text{V}$ across a coin. The current in the coin is $0.75\,\text{A}$. Calculate the resistance of the coin.
The circuit symbol for the thermistor is wrong. Which option shows the correct circuit symbol for a thermistor?

Choose one option.

A: pd across battery – pd across thermistor
B: pd across battery + pd across thermistor
C: pd across battery × pd across thermistor
D: pd across battery ÷ pd across thermistor

How could the potential difference (pd) across the resistor be calculated? ___
markScheme: 1 mark: A (pd across battery – pd across thermistor)

parts.text:
At one temperature, the thermistor in Figure 2 has a resistance of $200\,\Omega$.

Choose from: 0.0 V, 1.0 V, 1.5 V, 2.0 V.

What is the potential difference across the thermistor at this temperature? Give a reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: reason: thermistor has same resistance as resistor / equal resistance so pd shared equally (half the total)

parts.text: Figure 3 shows how the resistance of the thermistor varies with temperature. When the temperature is $10^{\circ}\,\mathrm{C}$, the resistance is $600\,\Omega$. Calculate the change in resistance when the temperature increases from $10^{\circ}\,\mathrm{C}$ to $15^{\circ}\,\mathrm{C}$.

Student A investigated how the current in resistor R at constant temperature varied with the potential difference across the resistor. Student A recorded both positive and negative values of current. Describe a method Student A could use for this investigation.
markScheme: Level 3 (5–6): Method would lead to a valid outcome; all key steps identified and logically sequenced.
Level 2 (3–4): Most steps identified but plan not fully logically sequenced / may not lead to valid outcome.
Level 1 (1–2): Some relevant steps but would not lead to valid outcome; links unclear.

Indicative points: measure current with ammeter; measure p.d. with voltmeter; vary variable resistor / cells / supply; record range of I and V; keep current low to avoid heating; switch off between readings; reverse resistor connections to get negative values; plot I–V graph.

parts.text: Student B repeated the investigation, but the temperature of resistor R increased. Explain how the increased temperature would have affected Student B’s results.
markScheme: 1 mark: current and p.d. would not be directly proportional / I–V graph not straight (curved)
1 mark: because resistance of R increases with temperature

parts.text: Figure 2 shows the scale on a moving coil ammeter. What is the resolution of the moving coil ammeter?

Student B replaced the moving coil ammeter with a digital ammeter. The digital ammeter has a higher resolution. Give one other reason why it would have been better to use the digital ammeter throughout this investigation.
markScheme: 1 mark: e.g. less chance of misreading / no parallax error / gives reading closer to true value (more accurate)

parts.text: Figure 1 shows overhead power cables in the National Grid. Explain the advantage of transmitting electricity at a very high potential difference.
markScheme: 1 mark: very high p.d. means very low current for same power
1 mark: less energy transferred to surroundings / less power loss in cables

parts.text: It is dangerous to fly a kite near an overhead power cable. The person could receive a fatal electric shock if the kite was very close to, but not touching, the power cable. Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: electric field strength is very high near the cable
1 mark: air becomes ionised / breaks down and conducts
1 mark: kite/string conducts charge to the person/earth

parts.text: Figure 3 shows the relationship between potential difference and distance when the air is dry. When humidity increases, air becomes a better conductor. Draw a line on Figure 3 to show how potential difference changes with distance if the humidity increases.
markScheme: 1 mark: line drawn below existing line for all values (lower p.d. for same distance)

parts.text: Figure 4 shows a cross-section through a power cable. A 1 metre length of a single aluminium wire is a better conductor than a 1 metre length of the steel wire. The individual wires behave as if they are resistors connected in parallel. Explain why the current in the steel wire is different to the current in a single aluminium wire.
markScheme: 1 mark: potential difference across the parallel wires is the same
1 mark: steel wire has greater resistance so carries less current (I = V/R)
